column61: Australia must transition away from fossil fuel energy as rapidly as possible. We must set clear and ambitious targets for 2030. We must not build any more gas or coal plants, and we must close existing ones as soon as we can. We should compensate communities which rely on coal mining and give assistance for retraining. We must fund clean energy systems. We must offer subsidies for Australians to have solar panels and we must prioritise battery storage to be available widely. We must encourage and facilitate the buying of electric vehicles and help those of low incomes to transition from combustion vehicles. These policies should be implemented immediately and be fully running by the end of this decade.

column324: It is important to take into consideration ALL aspects of various strategies, as there is no simple answer. Humans need space to live and we are not likely to forgo most of our convenient lifestyle, so this will impact on the environment, so we need to seek ways to maintain a healthy balance. Green energy, for example, is good, but what damage is caused in the production of solar panels, wind turbines, etc, and how can they be handled when no longer usable, so do we create further problems by seemingly using green, renewable energy. Animals may create methane gases, but they also produce clean and natural fertiliser, unlike the chemical versions produced in pollution causing factories. Striking the right balance is a difficult but important issue.
